reviews.text: Platinum Games is seemingly at a crossroads [...] Then Legend of Korra came and pumped the breaks a bit on expectations. [...] I hope this isn’t the type of product they’re going to focus on in the future.
From minute one, asking me to mandatorily link my Square Enix account [...] first emotional experience with the game was anxiety.
My first-impression blues didn’t get any better once I was asked to navigate a weird browser UI for seasonal news [...] You also can’t delete your characters for some reason.
The ability to equip vanity attire (transmog) shows [...] care about the design of how characters look and operate in a granular way.
Visually, Babylon’s Fall has gotten a little better since the shaky reveal, but it’s still rough [...] repeat enemies.
When you’re actually fighting stuff, it’s a ton of fun [...] mixing and matching ranged and melee attacks showcases the potential of the system.
You see that room in the above screenshot? I’ve been there like over 100 times [...] challenges are the same hallways, remixed.
The menus are, surprisingly, a big point of contention [...] UI is sluggish.
Babylon’s Fall is $60 [...] seeing the daily login bonuses pop up [...] battle pass feels like a trap.
It’s a live service game [...] lifespans are dependent on players pumping money in.
I actually really enjoyed many aspects of the story [...] I wish it was either a fully single-player game.
When combat is clicking in the moment [...] it’s easy to forget about Babylon’s Fall’s issues.
elements like the sound design that are trying to feel stylish, but stumble due to what could be time constraints.
some really bizarre (and enjoyable) English voice acting choices (Japanese audio is in too if you can’t deal)
the little moments between missions where characters are just chatting at a tavern show the potential of this world
in Monster Hunter when you load into a sandbox, it errs on the side of feeling open? Well Babylon’s Fall offers linear dungeons instead of sandboxes...
This game is a house of cards!
Babylon’s Fall is $60, with a $99.99 digital deluxe edition.
